column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Observe Variable Stars
#Text=Variable stars are , as the name suggests , stars that vary in brightness .
#Text=There are several different mechanisms as to how this happens .
#Text=Variable stars can be very interesting to observe , and this is one of the areas where amateur astronomy can make significant contributions .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Finding Variable Stars
#Text=Go out stargazing .
#Text=It sounds obvious , but this will be easier if you go out a few times and familiarise yourself with the stars and constellations .
#Text=Identify a star that you want to observe .
#Text=Decent variable stars have been studied for hundreds of years .
#Text=Algol , Mira and Delta Cephei ( δ Cep ) are all good ( if common ) choices .
#Text=For this article , we 're going to be observing δ Cep .
#Text=Find a couple of non-variable stars ( guide stars ) near your star .
#Text=This works with one , but two is better , and three or more ( if possible ) is even better .
#Text=These stars should be of a similar brightness to the star you are observing .
#Text=For δ Cep , you can use ζ Cep , which is slightly brighter than δ Cep at max brightness , and ε Cep , which is slightly brighter than δ Cep at min brightness .
#Text=Compare how bright the variable star is to the guide stars every night .
#Text=You should see it change brightness over time . δ Cep changes on a constant 5.37 day period .
#Text=Recording Your Observations
#Text=Get yourself a small notebook and a pencil .

#Text=If you need a flashlight , place a red filter over the top of the lens when the light shines through ; using a flashlight without doing this will ruin your night vision and make observation of these stars seem impossible .
#Text=At the top , write down the name of the star you are observing .
#Text=If you want , write down it 's co-ordinates and how much it is meant to vary by .
#Text=You can find the magnitudes quite easily by searching for the star on Wikipedia .
#Text=Underneath , write down your guide stars .
#Text=Again , you can write down their positions and brightness .
#Text=Every night , record how bright your target star is compared to the guide stars .
#Text=Write down the date and time as well , so you know when you took the observation .
#Text=Try drawing a light curve .
#Text=This is a graph of how your star varies over time .
#Text=A light curve can help you to identify what type of variable star you are observing .
#Text=If your star has regular variations , it can help you predict how bright it is going to be on the next night .
#Text=Prepare to take lots of observations .
#Text=δ Cep varies through visible brightness over 5.37 days , so it is quite easy to observe .
#Text=Mira varies on a 332 day period , and most of the time it requires a telescope to see , so it requires drastically more observations .
#Text=Identifying What Type of Variable You are Observing
#Text=Understand the main types of variable star .
#Text=These types generally have regular and predictable variations .
#Text=Cepheid variables have well-defined , stable periods and amplitudes .
#Text=They oscillate between fixed maxima and minima , and take a fixed amount of time to do it .
#Text=Cepheids can have periods between 1 and 50 days .
#Text=They have something called a period-luminosity relationship :
#Text=how long it takes to complete one cycle depends on the intrinsic brightness of the star .
#Text=This makes it possible to calculate how far away the star is .
#Text=RR Lyrae variables are similar to Cepheids , but they are dimmer , and have smaller periods and amplitudes .
#Text=They follow a period-luminosity relationship in the infrared , not in visible light .
#Text=Mira variables are red in colour , and have long periods , over 100 days , and very large variations .
#Text=The maxima and minima also vary , so one cycle can be slightly brighter or dimmer than another .
#Text=Mira variables are typically very dim , and need a telescope to see .
#Text=Algol variables are a type of binary star .
#Text=On occasion , the dimmer star eclipses the brighter one , causing the brightness to drop for a short period .
#Text=Slow irregular variables , as the name suggests , vary slowly and irregularly .
#Text=These stars do n't have a period .
#Text=They are typically large , red stars at the end of their life , which causes them to flicker irregularly .
#Text=TX Piscium is a slow irregular variable .
#Text=Understand the rarer types of variable stars .
#Text=These typically need a telescope or some binoculars to see .

#Text=Also , they do n't usually vary all the time , but spend most of their time at one brightness , and rarely and unpredictably change in brightness . they are sometimes known , as a whole , as eruptive variables .
#Text=Flare stars spend most of their time at a dim brightness , and occasionally , for a few minutes , jump up in brightness .
#Text=It is believed that this is caused by a similar mechanism to solar flares .
#Text=Proxima Centauri and Barnard 's star are flare stars .
#Text=Recurrent novae are similar to flare stars , but they have much greater jumps in brightness , and flare-ups are a lot rarer .
#Text=T Coronae Borealis , the Blaze Star , is a recurrent nova .
#Text=It has been seen to flare twice , once in 1886 and once in 1946 .
#Text=Some activity was seen in 2016 that suggests it may flare again soon .
#Text=R Coronae Borealis variables spend most of their time at maximum brightness .
#Text=At unpredictable intervals , their brightness plummets , then slowly works its way back up .
#Text=This is caused by carbon dust forming into soot , blotting out the light from the star .
#Text=Supernovae are rare , transient events caused by exploding stars .
#Text=Supernovae are incredibly bright , but seeing one with the naked eye can be a once in a lifetime event .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Do not look at the sun .
#Text=You will go blind .
